content.title: Ischemic Stroke Definition and Classification
content.summary: Acute neurologic deficit from focal cerebral ischemia due to arterial occlusion
key_points: Time-critical: 'Time is brain' - 1.9 million neurons/minute lost
IV tPA window: 4.5 hours from symptom onset
Mechanical thrombectomy for LVO: up to 24 hours in selected patients
TOAST classification: large artery, cardioembolic, small vessel, other, cryptogenic

statement.text: Ischemic stroke is a sudden focal neurological deficit caused by cerebral, spinal, or retinal infarction. It results from occlusion of a cerebral artery by thrombus or embolus, leading to brain tissue death within the affected vascular territory. Rapid reperfusion (IV thrombolysis and/or thrombectomy) is essential to minimize permanent damage.
statement.formal: Ischemic Stroke = Focal neurologic deficit + Cerebral infarction on imaging + Arterial occlusion → Time-critical reperfusion

explanation.intuition: A stroke is like a 'brain attack' - part of the brain suddenly loses blood supply, and brain cells start dying within minutes. The core (center) dies first, surrounded by a penumbra of at-risk tissue that can be saved with quick reperfusion.
explanation.key_insight: The concept of the ischemic penumbra is central: tissue at risk but not yet dead. The goal of acute stroke treatment is to reperfuse before penumbra becomes core. This is why time-based (tPA within 4.5h) and perfusion-based (thrombectomy with mismatch) criteria matter.

definitions_glossary.ischemic_stroke: Cerebral infarction from arterial occlusion causing focal neurologic deficit
definitions_glossary.penumbra: Ischemic but viable brain tissue surrounding infarct core; salvageable with reperfusion
definitions_glossary.NIHSS: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale - standardized stroke severity assessment
definitions_glossary.thrombolysis: Pharmacologic clot dissolution using IV alteplase (tPA) or tenecteplase
definitions_glossary.mechanical_thrombectomy: Endovascular clot retrieval for large vessel occlusion
definitions_glossary.large_vessel_occlusion: Occlusion of ICA, M1/M2 MCA, basilar - candidates for thrombectomy
definitions_glossary.TOAST_classification: Stroke etiology categories: large artery, cardioembolic, small vessel, other, cryptogenic
definitions_glossary.thrombotic_stroke: Stroke from in-situ thrombus formation at stenotic vessel
definitions_glossary.lacunar_stroke: Small vessel (<15mm) deep brain infarct from lipohyalinosis
definitions_glossary.time_is_brain: Concept emphasizing urgency: 1.9 million neurons die per minute

pathophysiology.mechanism: Arterial occlusion → ischemia → ATP depletion → ion pump failure → calcium influx → excitotoxicity → cell death. Core tissue (CBF <10ml/100g/min) dies within minutes; penumbra (CBF 10-22ml/100g/min) can survive hours if reperfused.

TOAST_etiologies.large_artery_atherosclerosis: >50% stenosis of relevant artery; carotid, intracranial atherosclerosis
TOAST_etiologies.cardioembolic: AF (most common), mechanical valve, LV thrombus, endocarditis
TOAST_etiologies.small_vessel_lacunar: Lipohyalinosis of penetrating arteries; pure motor, sensory, or ataxic hemiparesis
TOAST_etiologies.cryptogenic: No cause identified despite workup; consider occult AF, PFO

clinical_features: Face droop, arm weakness, speech difficulty (FAST)

imaging.CT_head: Rule out hemorrhage (required before tPA); acute ischemia may be subtle
imaging.CT_perfusion: Core vs penumbra mismatch for extended window thrombectomy
imaging.MRI_DWI: Detects ischemia within minutes (DWI positive); most sensitive

IV_thrombolysis.window: 4.5 hours from symptom onset (3h for some exclusion criteria)

mechanical_thrombectomy.indication: Large vessel occlusion (ICA, M1, M2, basilar) with favorable imaging
mechanical_thrombectomy.window: Up to 24 hours with favorable penumbral imaging (DAWN, DEFUSE-3 criteria)
mechanical_thrombectomy.benefit: NNT ~2.5 for functional independence; most effective stroke treatment

supportive_care: DVT prophylaxis after 24h if no hemorrhage

secondary_prevention.antiplatelets: Aspirin, clopidogrel, DAPT for 21-90 days high-risk TIA/minor stroke
secondary_prevention.anticoagulation: For cardioembolic (AF) - start after imaging shows no hemorrhagic transformation
secondary_prevention.carotid_intervention: CEA or CAS for symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50%

definition.@value: Acute focal neurologic deficit from cerebral, spinal, or retinal infarction due to arterial occlusion

learning_objectives: Define ischemic stroke and penumbra concept
Apply NIHSS for stroke severity assessment
Determine tPA eligibility within time window
Classify stroke etiology using TOAST criteria
clinical_pearls: Every minute counts: 1.9 million neurons die per minute of ischemia
Thrombectomy NNT ~2.5 - most effective treatment in medicine
NIHSS ≥6 suggests LVO - get CTA early
Permissive HTN (up to 220/120) before reperfusion; lower targets after
Cryptogenic stroke in young: consider PFO, dissection, occult AF

sources.source: Powers WJ, et al. 2019 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guideline. Stroke 2019
Nogueira RG, et al. DAWN Trial. N Engl J Med 2018
